newsitem.title: USA: Speeding stop nets State of Florida $235,000.
newsitem.headline: Speeding stop nets State of Florida $235,000.

text.p: A Florida highway patrolman pulled over an Illinois man for speeding this week and discovered more than $235,000, which Gunred Johnson signed over to the state along with his truck, police said Thursday.
Johnson, 60, of Oswego, Illinois, was stopped for speeding Wednesday on Interstate 10, just west of Tallahassee, a department spokesman said.
When the trooper neared the 1994 Dodge pickup, he noticed a strong smell of fabric softener and detergent, both products used to hide the odour of illegal drugs, the spokesman said.
Johnson allowed police to search the truck and then told police he had no idea of the source of money in plastic bags hidden in a compartment accessible through the truck's wheel well.
Police said Johnson told them he visited a friend in St. Augustine and was on his way to Memphis, Tennessee, to gamble.
Lieut. Ken Knowles, a Florida Highway Patrol spokesman, said a thorough search at police headquarters turned up $235,230 in $100, $50 and $20 bills.
A computer search found no outstanding warrants for Johnson, who signed the money and the truck over to police and was released. He then reportedly took a Greyhound bus to Illinois.
"We had no reason to hold him further, so we issued him his traffic citation, which is only an infraction," Knowles said. "He can mail in the fine in 30 days."
Johnson now owes the state of Florida $110.
